fields.headline: Forward planning
fields.bodyText: Now-Feb 5 Party nights at the Eden Project Cornwall's Eden Project has kicked off the festive season with Party Nights (Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays until 10pm), featuring a covered ice-rink, a lantern parade, fire sculptures and mince pies and mulled wine in the Morocco and Zzubb Zzubb restaurants. Where: Eden Project, near St Austell, Cornwall. How much: £12 per adult for an all-day pass (£8 from 3.30pm); free for under 16s throughout the Party Nights Season. Skating is £3 extra; www.edenproject.com . Dec 26, Jan 1 Junkanoo, Bahamas Dance in extraordinary paper costumes to the sound of bells, whistles and goombay drums. The festival began to allow slaves time off to party. Where: Bay Street and Shirley Street, Nassau, 2am-9am . How much: Free to stand (but space is limited), buy tickets online or at the parade (www.junkanoo.com ). Dec 29-Jan 1 Edinburgh Hogmanay Edinburgh's New Year's party should go with a bang, as Christophe Berthonneau (responsible for the Eiffel tower's millennial illumination) is planning pyrotechnics to remember. There's a Torchlight Procession on Dec 29 which winds its way through the city centre, the French-flavoured Night Afore carnival on Dec 30 and the Royal Bank Street Party on New Year's Eve is expected to attract 100,000 revellers. How much: Royal Bank Street Party Pass £2.50. Concert in the Gardens from £30 (0131-473 2000, www.edinburghshogmanay.org ). Dec 27-31 Festival of the Sea Goddess (Iemanjá), Rio Flowers, perfume, champagne and all things shiny are offered at sunrise on the beaches of Rio de Janeiro to Iemanjá, the Orixa or goddess of the sea. In the afternoon, worshippers clad all in white carry wooden ships bearing the statue of the goddess to the sea. Where: Copacabana, Ipanema and Leblon beaches. How much: Free to watch, one flower costs one real (about 20p). Dec 31 Midnight Run, New York The four-mile Midnight Run in Central Park is a New Year's Eve event for fitness fanatics. DJs, a masquerade parade and fireworks are all part of the celebration, and there's a toast of (non-alcoholic) bubbly at the halfway mark. The Masquerade Parade begins in front of the Central Park Bandshell just south of the 72nd St Transverse. Where: Central Park, New York. DJ music and dancing 10pm, costume parade and contest 11pm, fireworks and four-mile race midnight. How much: Free to watch, $25-35 to participate. New York Road Runners Club (001 212 860 4455, www.nyrrc.org ). Online registration closes 26 Dec. Jan 6-9 Elvis Presley Birthday Celebration Elvis Presley would be blowing out 70 candles on his birthday cake if he hadn't died in 1977. Each year, fans celebrate at a free ceremony on the lawns of Graceland and Memphis hosts concerts, treasure hunts and exhibitions. Where: Graceland, Memphis, Tennessee (www.elvis.com ). How much: Birthday ceremony free, Charity bash $30. Jan 8-30 Sydney Festival Celebrate summer in January with world-class theatre, music, art and dance at Australia's number one cultural festival. Where: Landmark Sydney locations including the Opera Forecourt, Sydney Olympic Park and Parramatta. How much: Some events are free (www.sydneyfestival.org.au ).
